description: From Middle English riden, from Old English rīdan, from Proto-West Germanic *rīdan, from Proto-Germanic *rīdaną, from Proto-Indo-European *Hreydʰ-, from Proto-Indo-European *h₃reyH-.

entries.meaning: An instance of riding.
examples: Can I have a ride on your bike?
We took the horses for an early-morning ride in the woods.
go for a quick ride

entries.meaning: (informal) A vehicle.
examples: That's a nice ride; what did it cost?
pimp my ride

entries.meaning: An amusement ridden at a fair or amusement park.
examples: the kids went on all the rides

entries.meaning: A lift given to someone in another person's vehicle.
examples: Can you give me a ride home?

entries.meaning: (UK) A road or avenue cut in a wood, for riding; a bridleway or other wide country path.
(UK, dialect, archaic) A saddle horse.
(Ireland) A person (or sometimes a thing or a place) that is visually attractive.
examples: Absolutely, and I agree about Madonna. An absolute ride *still*. :-) M.

entries.meaning: (music) In jazz, a steady rhythmical style.
A wild, bewildering experience of some duration.
examples: That story was a ride from start to finish.

entries.meaning: (slang) An act of sexual intercourse
examples: Synonyms: shag, fuck, cop, bang
I gave my boyfriend a ride before breakfast.

verbs.description: ride (third-person singular simple present rides, present participle riding, simple past rode or (obsolete) rade or (obsolete) rid, past participle ridden or (now colloquial and nonstandard) rode)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, transitive) To transport oneself by sitting on and directing a horse, later also a bicycle etc. [from 8th c., transitive usage from 9th c.]
examples: I ride to work every day and park the bike outside the office.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, transitive) To be transported in a vehicle; to travel as a passenger. [from 9th c., transitive usage from 19th c.]
examples: In an elaborately built, indoor San Francisco, passengers ride cable cars through quiet, hilly streets.

entries.meaning: (transitive, informal, chiefly US and South Africa) To transport (someone) in a vehicle. [from 17th c.]
examples: The cab rode him downtown.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) Of a ship: to sail, to float on the water. [from 10th c.]
(transitive, intransitive) To be carried or supported by something lightly and quickly; to travel in such a way, as though on horseback. [from 10th c.]
examples: The witch cackled and rode away on her broomstick.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To traverse by riding.
examples: Early women tobogganists rode the course in the requisite attire of their day: skirts. In spite of this hindrance, some women riders turned in very respectable performances.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To convey, as by riding; to make or do by riding.
examples: How many races have you ridden this year?

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To support a rider, as a horse; to move under the saddle.
examples: A horse rides easy or hard, slow or fast.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, transitive, slang) To mount (someone) to have sex with them; to have sexual intercourse with. [from 13th c.]
examples: She rode him hard, and he squeezed her breasts, and she came again.

entries.meaning: (transitive, colloquial) To nag or criticize; to annoy (someone). [from 19th c.]
examples: “One old boy started riding me about not having gone to Vietnam; I just spit my coffee at him, and he backed off.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) Of clothing: to gradually move (up) and crease; to ruckle. [from 19th c.]
examples: In athletics, triple jumper Ashia Hansen advises a thong for training because, while knickers ride up, ‘thongs have nowhere left to go’: but in Beijing Britain's best are likely, she says, to forgo knickers altogether, preferring to go commando for their country under their GB kit.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To rely, depend (on). [from 20th c.]
examples: With so much riding on the new payments system, it was thus a grave embarrassment to the government when the tariff for 2006-07 had to be withdrawn for amendments towards the end of February.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) Of clothing: to rest (in a given way on a part of the body). [from 20th c.]
examples: She's wearing inky-blue jeans that ride low enough on her hips that her aquamarine thong peeks out teasingly at the back.

entries.meaning: (lacrosse) To play defense on the defensemen or midfielders, as an attackman.
To manage insolently at will; to domineer over.
examples: The nobility […]  could no longer endure to be ridden by bakers, coblers[sic], brewers, and the like.

entries.meaning: (surgery) To overlap (each other); said of bones or fractured fragments.
(radio, television, transitive) To monitor (some component of an audiovisual signal) in order to keep it within acceptable bounds.
examples: vocal riding

entries.meaning: (music) In jazz, to play in a steady rhythmical style.
examples: The quintet in Propheticape muses out-of-measured-time until Holland leads it into swift, riding jazz.
